div.head: THE MAHMÛÜDIEH CANAL.
div.p: The question of the extension, of the Mah- inoudieh Canal» efficiency "by making a new branch to the sea to the west is of vital importance to Alexandria. Alexandria depends for its connection with the rest of Egypt main ly on the canal and the railway, and a considerable part of thé exporta and importa are transported by canal, especially since the Government abolished the bridge tolls. The city's trade is developing enormously, and a* the gate of Egypt Alexandria is much in need | of facilities for expediting its traffic with the interior. At the present time the Canal can J only do it* work with great difficulty and frequently there is considerable congestion on tins water-way. In another column of to-day's issue we publish a letter from a correspondent, who is much averse to-the scheme of making a new branch to the westward. Instead, he suggests that the Canal should be wide trod by means of expropriations on the city side to the extent of forty metres in breadth. The sur face of the ground which would have to be expropriated is, however, occupied for the most part by buildings, and the cost of expropriation would bo enormous. On the other hand, a canal passing westward through the. Gabluin quarter would be of such immense advantage to the proprietors of the land in the neighbourhood that, in order to enliance the value of their property, they declare that they are willing to cedfl the necessary land for making the canal gratin to the Egyptian Government.
Our correspondent apparently labours finder the impression that the project is in danger of being carried out Without any preli

minary study, and consequently the interests of the varions corporations will , not be sufficiently taken intoXxjnsideration. This is, however, quite erroneous. The Egyptian Government has always made a point of consulting the import and export trades of Alexandria before taking any measure that might jeopardise thbir interesta. We have no doubt bat that the Government will do so in the present case. As to the position of the Alexandria Municipality in this matter,, we need merely state that the only step that has up to now been taken has been the communication to that body of the project of the new branch of the Canal. This scheme was submitted to the Municipality a few months ago in order to be studied by the members of the Municipal Commission. It was carefully drawn up by the able engineering authority* of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, M. Malavel, who' may be called the originator of the ides of the now branch. - The project has toot yet been brought officially to the cognizance of the members of the Municipal Commission. One of the first conditions that the Municipality was prepared to insist upon was that in no way should the free flow of the existing canal be impeded lest in any case the purity of the present intake of the Alexandria Water Company should vbs endangered by havtfig a stagnant body of water existing below the site of the intake. Since then the question' has remained in statu quo. The Government! has now1 to give a decision on the matter, and will then doubtless consult the Municipality in order to take its opinion as to the advisability of proceeding with the projeot. As regarda the Irrigation Department, trie scheme for a new maritime canal has been brought'to the notice of the Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt, but as yet no definite steps have been taken. A new branch does not offer any objection from the point of view of irrigation, as it does not entail the Irrigation Department's giving any more water, which is the main consideration with that department.

The actual scheme is the construction of a new salt-water canal running at ses level from Gabbari to Nouxha, where it would step up to the canal level by means of locks. It is obvious that such à scheme has many advantages. It prevents the silting up of the harbour, will improve the railway comniunications, relieve the congestion on the M&hiuoudieh Canal, and improve the sanitary condition of the port During the last four years the number of boats passing through the Meooufieh head lock at '-the barrage has more than quadrupled and the number of boats passing through the tail lock of the Mahmou- dieh Canal shows a similar increase. In 1905 the number of boats passing Kafr Dawar up and down stream was 90,438, and annually k20,500 boats ply on the Npusha-lliitet-el- Bassal reach. The congestion grows worse every day, and the construction of the new branch is impérative, for it is the only solution out of the difficulty. Alexandria is growing rapidly, and will inevitably become not only the great putlet torEgypt's railway traffic, but tor the greater part of Africa. The Cape-to Cairo Railway scheme may yet be far from being a "fait accompli," but there is sure to be a complete system of communications between North and South Africa by r ail, river, and lake in a few years' time, and the outlet for this traffic will be at Alexandria. The growth of the town westward 'will in a few years' time lead to one uninterrupted mass of buildings stretchingJrora Gabbari to Mex and occupying every available site between sea and lake. Unlesa, therefore, a decision id arrived at soon the scheme will not be feasible without enormous extra cost for expropriations. At the present time the land- owners interested in the promotion of the project are prepared to cede to the Egyptian Government free of any charge, the land necessary- for making the new branch and they are ready to construct the canal under the supervision of the Government. They •further offer to give facilities for connecting the goods station at Gabbari through the Gabbari quarter with the new quays to the west Under such favourable conditions .the new maritime canal could easily be constructed, »nd jt is to be hoped that the $overmaent will not lose the opportunity, for soon, owing to the rise in the value of the land consequent on the development of the City westward, the canal will never have a chance to be made without very great expense.

div.p: Owing to fever being prevalent in the Cairo prisons, the authorities have deoided to prohibit the prisoners from being visited by their relatives until further notice.

div.head: The Weather,
div.p: The thick fog which prevailed at Alexandria this morning caused a good deal of delay to shipping, the mail and other steamers being unable to enter the pass up to the time of our going to pre*s.

div.head: Alexandria Amateur Athletlo Club
div.p: By the coorteey of the committee of the British Club, the annual general meeting of the Alexandria Amatear Athletic Clnb will be held at the British Club on Thursday, 10th inst., at 5 30 p m.

div.head: Nil* Navigation.
div.p: A sadd is being constructed from the we*t bank of the Jfjle near Rsneh Barrage. The right side of the river alone is open for navigation and red lights have been fixed for night traffic at the end of the sadd.

div.head: Murdered by Robbers
div.p: A few days ago. a gang of robbers broke into an esbet near Nahieh Sejin, belonging to Bogbos Pasha Nobar, and mcrdered thegbeffir stationed there. Three of the gang have been arrested, bat the rest are still at Urge.

div.head: Haklma or Khartoum
div.p: The 8odsn Medical Department is arranging for a Hakima, attached to the Civil Hospita1, to reside in 'Khartoum. This is solely in the interests of the families of married Government employes and families of officers of the Egyptian Army.

div.head: Cairo Bourse
div.p: It is romoored that some members of the Committee of the Stock and Sharebrokers' Corporation at Cairo are eager to negotiate with an important firm ot Cairo brokers with ^ view to ooming to terms in order to settle the dispute which baa dragged for some considerable time now.

div.head: Military Lecture.
div.p: Tbe seventh military lectare of the winter season will be delivered by Captain J. A. j Byrne, 2nd Royal loniskilling Fusiliers, on | AwJ'Vk"™40°wom '0* 10 LE" lroro,'' at 6 p.m. on Tuesday evening next, in the Model Room at Headquarters, Cairo.

div.head: Exonarated.
div.p: Salatna Eff. Sarkis, Moawin of Miniah Mon dirieh, who was recently charged with embeszling a sum of Qoyernment money and with certain irregularities,has now been exone-the charge by the Supreme Council in of Discipline held at the Ministry of the ordered to resume Uiiadel and Mcbamed Aly

div.head: Arabic Art
div.p: The Committee for the Preservation of Monunments ol Arabio Art has only just issued the report on its work during 1905. The most interesting reading in the report is teappen dix by Henry Bey on the mosque El Mardani, that exquisite specimen of Arabic art of the fourteenth century in the Darb el-Ahmar. It WM one of the finest edifices created during the reign of Bn-Nasr ibn Kalsoon, and like many other mosques in Cairo had been falling into ruin, but has now been restored. Tbe article is well illustrated.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN QUESTION.
The "Temps" on Autonomy
div.p: The Bulletin of the "Temps" deals with the question of Egypt. It considers it certain that England, when she judges Egypt riper for autonomy, will grant it to her. It remains for the Egyptians to prepare a liberal fotnre for themselves by peace and industry. (Havas)

div.head: COLLISION AT SUEZ
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRKSPONDIMT.) Yesterday morning, at 1 o'olock, while the Dutch steamer Timor was under weigh in 8urz roads to enter the Canal, the S.S. Knowsley Rail, which was at the time coming on to her anchorage from the Red Sea, ran into her and damaged her amidships, above the water line. Tbe damage would have been mnoh greater, however, had the latter steamer not reversed her engines.

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT'S VISIT
div.p: We are authorised to contradict the state men of a morning contemporary to the effect that the Dike of Connaught, on the occasion of his forthcoming visit to Egypt, will stay at Abdeen Palace.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H H. the Khedive, who spent yesterday at Konbbeh Palace, went this morning to Ismailia to inspect his estates there. His Highness returns to Koubbeh this evening, and to-morrow morning will go to Abdeen, to hold the anunal reception on the anniversary oi his HighneBs's accession.

div.head: THB SUCRERIES COMPANY
div.p: On Saturday last the hearing of the case of A. Felonioo and partners against the adminis tration of the Supreries Company was postponed until the 29th proxo., when it will come on for hearing before a special sitting of tbe Commercial Mixed Court at Cairo

div.head: UNION FONCIEUE
div.p: The Union Foncifrre d'Egypte has just oon eluded an excellent purchase of the finest agricultural land in the Behera Province from the Daira Rbassa, the Daira having sold 2,300 feddans to the company

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITY.
div.p: Thecommittee of the proposed University, composed of 15 members, have decided to inorease their number to 25, by selecting 10 more aotive members, two of whom will be Dr. Alwi Pasha and Yonssef Bey Saddik. Hassan Pasha ohsen and Hafi Bey Hl Mansbawi have subscribed £500 and £100, respectively, to the funds.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageriea Mantimes 8 S Congo, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday, arid is due at Alexandria to morrow The Buerman liner Britannia sailed from Malta on Saturday afternoon, and is due here on Wednesday morning with pasrergers.

div.head: Waterspout at Piraeus
MANY WRECKS.
div.p: A despatch from Piraeus reports that a waterspout has burst over that port. Four steamers foundered, and numerous smaller craft were wrecked. The 8 S. Stephano Strait, of the Diakaki Line, from Egypt, was driven by the tempest on to a British oollier discharging Damage was done to the extent of £5,000.

div.head: MACEDONIA-AUSTRIAN INTERVENTION.
div.p: A meeting took plaoe last week between the Austrian Ambassador in Constantinople and His Holiness the (Eonmenical Patriarob, who assured the Marqnis Pallavioini that his earnest prayer was for peace between the rival factions in Macedonia.

div.head: BANK OF ABY8SINIA.
div.p: Tbe following paragraph appeared in Saturday's issne of "La Reforme." We have been unable to obtain any confirmation of the truth of the statements from any of the authorised sources of information in Cairo. As all information is officially refused, it must be presumed that our contemporary' statements do not admit of a categorical contradiction. The paragraph is as follows:— Nos renseignements none permettent d'affirmer que des dissentimenta tres serieox existent eutre Sir'John Harrington et M. Gili- vray et que la presence an Caire da premier de oes messieurs n'est pas etrangere aux difficultes nees de oette radsintelligenoe. Nous avons de raisons de oroire qne In demission de Sir John Harrington est beau coup pins probable qne oelle de M MaoQili- vray qni, vraisemblablement, retonmera poor qnelque temps enoore en Abyssinie. Nous ajonterons qne lea agents frar^ris et italieus k Addis Abeba seront trhs probablement rem- plac^s 6galement. Nous avons de serienx motifs de penser qne ces renseignea ents se venfieront dans nn asset bref delai.

div.head: THE RECENT EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: With reference to Mr. Keeling's letter regarding the reoent earthquake shock, our Table correspondent writes — We felt the shock here twice on the twenty sixth ultimo. The first shock occurred precisely at 9 a m., and lasted about 30 seoonds, causing a good deal of rocking of chairs, craokling, etc. The second took place at 3 55 pm, and was more felt than the first, lasting about 30 seconds.

div.head: VISIT OF A LEVIATHAN
div.p: A notable event in the local shipping world this season will be the arrival here of the S.S. Caronia. Such magnifioent steamers connecting Egypt with Europe and America will considerably increase the number of tourists wishing to visit us, and we must congratulate the Canard Line on sending this modern leviathan here on a special trip. She sailed from New York on the 5th, and will arrive at Alexandria on the 19th inst, returning to New York the following day, via Fiume and Naples.

div.head: DEAN BUTCHER TESTIMONIAL FUND.
div.p: For the convenience of those visitors to Cairo who may wish to subscribe to tho above fund, the managers of the various Hotels in Cairo have kindly consented to receive contributions at their cash office, where a report of the meeting at the British Agency on November 28 can be seen. Subscriptions from residents and visitors may also be paid into the National Bank of Egypt, or be sent to the bon, treasurer, Mr R. H. Do Boulay, c/o the Egyp-Salt and Soda Co., Limited, Boalao.

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL.

Maofarlane, D.S 0., and officers, the band of the King's Own Scottish Borderers will play the following programme on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel on Tuesday, from 8 to 10 p.m. March — Directorate—Sousa. Valso—Uniss an Hannover—Labitzky a Threumerei lot. b Sohlummerlied I Rchu'n'nn Fantasia —Songs of all Nations Codfrwy Setvnata— Love in Idleness—Macbeth. Cornet Solo—Plains of Peaoe — Uarnard. div.head: SEASON AT LUXOR.
A SUCCESSFUL GYMKHANA.
div.p: Pending the opening of the Winter Palace Hotel, the season in Luxor is scarcely yet in tall swing, but the old-established Sporting Clnb has made a start by inaugurating the weekly Gymkhanas, and the opening meeting on Thursday last was well supported by the visitors at the hotels, and those on the Rameses. The grand-stand, with its gaily coloured awning and hen-coop seats, was fall of interested spectators, while carriages and picturesque groups of natives lined the other side of the oourse. The programme consisted of the usual events, i.e., sack race for natives, donkey boys' standing race, visitors' donkey race, water earners' race, visitors' goolah pegging raoe, buffalo race, horse race, and camel race. Some of these, such as the buffalo and water carriers' races, are perhaps unique in Gymkhanas and always cause great amusement, while the horse and camel raoes are really exciting to watch. The visitors' races were well supported, and the whole programme is carried through quickly and smoothly. A very pleasant little impromptu dance was given on Tuesday evening on board the Rameses, and was attended by some ot the passengers from Ramoses HI. and other visitors. The hotels at present open are filling rapidly, and there is no doobt that many intending visitors are only waiting to be accommodated at the wonderful new Palace, the last word in modern comfort and luxury, which has sprung up, as if by magic, on the river hank. Those who saw its beginning, less than twelve months ago, can scarcely believe 'hat the work is rapidly approaching completion, but such is indeed the case, end it is now only a question of days before the genial and popular manager, M. Lonis Schaiob, will throw open the doors and receive his many patrons. The German flag is at the present moment flying at the Luxor Hotel, in honour of Prince Franois of Bavaria, who is making a stay here, and an interesting personality, in the Earl of I Halsbary, was also bare until a day or two ago. The late Lord Chancellor and his party found their time well occupied in seeing all the wonders of antiquity which Luxor has to show. Of all there wonders none perhaps can compare with a first view of one of the great temples by moonlight, and the perfect weather and elear or drive to Karnak, and there to explain or ponder (according to their nature) over the spectacle of this marvellous group of rains, flooded by the beautiful and mysterious moonlight of Egypt.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all. to permlt—within certain necessary limit free discussion.

div.head: PORTE AND PATRIARCH To TUX EDITOR
div.p: or THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE Sir,—Some time ago,in a leading artiole.yoo reprodooed a letter ot the Constantinople correspondent of the "Times" on the Greek Church and the Porte, which reffered to the project of holding an Ecumencial Council at Constantinople as having fallen through in conseqnence ot the opposition of the Porte. The Orthodox Greek Patriarch of Alex andria, informed me in a recent audience, that there was not the least idea of holding an Ecumencial Council at Constantinople. It was simply to be a meeting of the three Patriarchs, similar to that held in 1879, [at which His Beatitude was secretary. The present Patriarch of Constantinople presided, the other Patriarchs being Sophronius of Alexandria and lerotheus of Jerusalem. An (Ecumenical Council would require the presence of the Episcopal Body in its entirety No such project was entertained. As for the Union of the Orthodox and Anglican Churches, I may state, on excellent authority, that all responsible representatives of of the Anglican Cbnroh do nothing more than encourage friendly relations with the Orthodox Greek Chnrch.—Yours efa, LAURAWVB MORTON Bolkeley, January 7.

div.head: CHESS CLUB FOR CAIRO
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE EGTPTLAN GAZETTE Dear Sir, I have the intention of starting a Chess Club in this city, having been asked by a number of amateurs in Cairo to try and get up one. I am sure that there are a good many amateurs in Cairo that would willingly join such a club if the idea were brought to their notice. As my connections in Cairo are not very large, I would ask you, if you can see your way to do so. To publish a notice relative to this idea in your paper, stating that amatenrs wishing to join should correspond with me as I secretary pro tem. Very likely there are also amateurs in Alexandria who would like to become corresponding members. Them is no better pastime, espeoially for yoong men, than chess, and 1 think it wonld answer a long felt want if a Chess Club in Cairo ooold be got op. The subscription wonld be very low, a few shillings per month, enough for our expenses. Thanking yon in anticipation, I remain, PAUL FRANK, P C Box 204, Cairo. P.8.—Naturally if I find enough encourage ment, I shall call a meeting here and then draw up statutes and elect a commitee. 29287-3-1) P.F.

div.head: NOTES FROM MENA.
SMALL DANCES AND MUSIC.
div.p: There is to be a dance at Mens House this Wednesday, and for the remainder of the season there will be a series of these enjoyable functions given every fortnight. Formal invitations from the management will not be issued; but friends of the visitors there will always be welcomed; and doubtless these popular evenings will be well patronised. For the convenience of those who live in Cairo a closed carriage service has been instituted, leaving the hotel at midnight, whereby the guests will be enabled to return comfortably at the small charge of some P.T. 20 per head.

Three afternoons in the week nowadays the verandab at Mena Honse is enlivened by masio, the services of the Neapolitan band, the Bistett, and the Ladies' Orchestra having been requisitioned on Monday, Tharaday, and Saturday. Sunday is always a popular day for visitors to tho Pyramids, and a constant stream of oarriages and visitors finds ita way to Mena for either Innoh er tea. Amongst those noticed on the verandab yesterday were Capt. and Mrs. Briley, the Misses Campbell, the Misses Anderson, Col. and Mrs. Ladlow, Mr. Armstrong, Mr. Radoliff, Capt and Mrs. Wilson, Capt. Stirling, Capt. Dawson, and many others. Mr. Alexander Nangovirh brought, a large party in his new car, and Mrs Kooh bad a number of guests for lunch, including Mr. Laykaof, who for many years was the champion skater of Vienna.
Mr. and Mrs Guy Repton are back again at Mena, and intend staying on till the latter end of the month, when they will in all probability leave for the Riviera.

Although H. B. Mastapha Pasha Fehmy has resumed his duties in Cairo, he is still staying at Mena, returning there every day as soon as his work is over ; and be will certainly remain in his present quarters till the end of the month.

Mrs. Montague Summers has well nigh recovered from her late indisposition, and is at the present moment bnsily employed in the good cause of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. No one can be long in Egypt without realizing how much this excellent work needs substantial encouragement,and we earnestly hope that the efforts now being made at Mena Honse may prove a very valuable assistance to the society.
Sir Nowell and Lady Salmon, with Mrs. Salmon, are still staying at Mena Hoase, as is also Mr. F.W. Sturge, the well-known painter.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
"LOS HUGUENOTS."
div.p: The "Hagnenots thanks to the admirable principals, and a distinct renaissance and vigour on the part of the orchestra and chorus - a most unexpected development. They kept up in the 5th act when the three, de Nangis, Marcel, and Valentine, are caught and dragged to their death. Indeed the Rataplan chorus was the only failure, and then only on account of a certain woodenness. Mile Karl was singing quite well. M. Mezy was good but not always perfectly tree. He seemed rather listless at times. Mile Devilloy was, as ever, delicious, timid, hot perfect when once launched into the roulades and trills which show her voice to such perfection. M Durand as St. Brea was admirable; thoughhe is perhaps rather passe. There are times when he and Escalais make all the rest appear amateurs. M Maas was also excellent, and his low notes especially were absolutely accurate—no such easy or usual feat I Mme Baron was not always on the note. She was inclined to sing sharp at moments; but her acting all through was very fine, and the duet in the 4th act could hardly have been bettered. Here Escalais shone . he showed us not merely lung power—and some accuse him of that and that only—but real and genuine passion, tone, colour. His great high notes, instinct with life and depth, made one hold one's breath. Tree, he took great liberties in the final trio, and would not bring out the contrast to the bass, but all through he showed what a thorough master he is of his own voice and the masic.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We regret to learn that Lord Cromer has been oonfined to bed for the last two days owing to slight indisposition.

Saad Pasha Zighlonl, Minister of Education, who is on a tour of inspection in Upper Egypt, arrived at Assiout on Saturday, and after visiting the Moudirieh and the Government school, prooeeded to Sobag.

Mr. Horace Rumbold leaves Cairo this morning for Madrid, where he will take up the post of seoond secretary to H.B.M.'s Embassy. We need not say that the departure of Mr. and Mis. Rumbold will leave a distinct gap in Cairo Sooiety. As second secretary to H.B.M.'s Agency, Mr. Rambold has done excellent work for many years, and his many friends will greatly regret his departure from Egypt.

The visit of the Radical Member for the Tyneside division of Northumberland to Egypt has aroused so much interest among the native population of the Capital that the following detail of that gentleman's career should be read with interest. Mr. John Mao kinnon Robertson is of Sootoh origin, and was born at Brodick, in the Isle of Arran, on the 14th November, 1856. He was educated at Stirling and left sohool at the age of thirteen. He joined the staff at the "Edinburgh Evening News" as leader writer in 1878 and came to London in 1884 to join the "National Reformer" of Mr. Bradlaogh. Alter the death ot that eminent Atheist in 1891, he edited the paper till its stoppage in 1893 Then he started the 'Free Review ' and edited it till 1895. He married Miss Maude Mosher, an Amerioan lady, in 1893, and has a son and a daaghter. In 1895 he stood as Independent Radical candidate for Northampton. In 1897 and 1898 he went to the United States on a lecturing tour and in 1900 he started for South Africa to investigate martial law in Cape Colony and Natal. While there he sent a number of letters to the "Morning Leader" signed "Scrotator." In 1903 he was chosen by the Tyneside Liberal Association as ita candidate, and got into Parliament at the last election. The interest he has taken in Egypt and Egyptian effrirs is well known.

Mr Robertson is a volnminons and able writer, and was one of the committee, with Huxley, Tyndall, Leslie Stephen, Haeckel, and other eminent men, who have done so much for free thought through the Rationalist Press Association. His publications Include the following works:—Modern Hamanists; Essays toward a Critical Method; Buckle and his Critics ; Montaigne and Shakespeare: The Saxon and the Celt; The Dynamics of Religion; History of Free Thought; Christianity and Mythology.
Mt. Gerolimato, H. B. M.'s Vioe-Consul at Harrar, has arrived at Cairo, and will come on to Alexandria in the course of the next few days.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: Family Hotel. Built in 1904. Between Shepheard's Hotel and the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
NEW MANAGEMENT. 29242-26-11-90

div.head:
FIGHTING IN MOROCCO
FLIGHT OF RAISULL.
CHEREEFLAN COMMANDER WOUNDED.

div.p: The Chereefian troops have attacked Zinat with artillery, losing 20 men and killing 50 of Raisuli's followers. The latter has fled to the mountains. Zinat has been set on fire. ( Havas)
Artillery shelled and partly destroyed E Raisuli's stronghold at Zinat. E Raisuli has fled to the mountains.
The commander of the Imperial force, who led the attack, and many others were wounded. Anjera Kah's tribesmen are joining the Saltan's army.

Seven Spanish officers and a proportionate number of non-oommissioned otfioers have ar rived here, prepared to commence the organisation of the police, in acoordance with the Algeciras Convention. (Ruter)
The Algerian Lieutenant Ben Sideraa has left Tangier with cannon, and led the Chereefian artillery in the destruction of Raisuli casba. The latter's flight into the mountains is confirmed. (Havas)

Pending the introduction into Parliament of a private bill for the construction of the Channel Tunnel, the most acute controversy, largely on party lines, is taking place. The Liberals welcome the prospect of closer ties with the Continent, while the Conservatives are opposing the scheme owing to fears of invasion. Lord Wolseley repeats his warning uttered in 18i2. The "Times" endorses its military correspondent's views, and points out that the scheme would only be permissible if conscription on Continental lines were adopted. (Reuter)

div.head:
FATAL LANDSLIP IN GERMANY.
SEVERAL BURIED ALIVE.

div.p: A portion of land collapsed daring the construction of the Rhine railway and two men were buried. A second collapse entombed a rescue party numbering from 30 to 40 men Fresh falls took place throughout the night. Up to the present 10 dead bodies have been recovered. 15 injured men have been removed after terrible suffering. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE BANK RATE.
PROSPECT OF REDUCTION.

div.p: The release of dividends has considerably eased the monetary stringency. It is expected in Lombard Street that the Bank rate will be reduced within a fortnight, unless the foreign monetary situation changes for the worse, (R.)

Six mounted robbers attacked the secretary of the German Legation and party, who were returning from hnnting, nineteen miles from here. A dozen shots were fired. The Germans escaped, but lost their baggage. The robbers resisted the cavalry sent to punish them, and killed a soldier. {Reuter)
An unknown man, supposed to be a Russian, entered a Bank here and demanded money. On being refused, he threw a bomb which killed himself and the cashier and injured several persons.
Later. The assassin has turned out to be a demented American Socialist. (Reuter)
The disturbances at Lodz, continue Ambulance work is rendered impossible by hooligans, who threaten to murder doctors attending to the wounded lying in the streets. (Reuter)
The Russian famine stricken provinces are presenting a large death-toll, chietly canelly starvation and exposure. {Reuter}
Viscount Selby and Sir E Satow have bred appointed members of the permanent Court at The Hague. (Feuter)
Footbol, Richmond. England beat France by 41 points to 18. (Feuter)

div.head: NOTES FROM CYPRUS
CHARITY BALL BAZAAR
div.p: The great eveut of last week was the charity bill held in Nicosia. It had received the aotive support of both English and Greek ladiep, who had formed themselves into a committee and planned and oarried out the arrangements with mach saooess. Lady King Harman was president of the committee, and among the most ardent supporters at its inception was Lady Hatohinsou, who, having now left Cyprus for Ceylon, was unfortunately nnable to be present.

Nicosia unhappily possesses ne public recrea 1 tioD room where entertainments on a moderate 1 scale can be given, and, onder these oironm- stanoes it was of the greatest possible advantage when the members of the Greek Commercial ( Clob generously placed th-ir premises at the disposal of the committee for the porposes of , the basaar. The building, which is oentrally situated near the Post Office, and facing the main , thoroughfare, consists of two spaoioas rooms, I unencumbered by maobfurniture, with another fair sizad-room leadingoff There were some four or five stalls tastefully deourated and in the oharge of English and Greek lady stallholders. Some Turk sh ladies contributed some pretty artiotes of embroidery wbioh found ready sale at one of the stalls. The show was opened at 2 p.m by Lady King Harman, who was presented by a Greek lady with a handsome bonqret of roses, and a short speech was made by bis Excellency the High Commissioner, commend ing the objects of the bazaar and expressing thanks to those who had by their liberal tffirts provided so many useful and ornamental articles, and to the members of the Commercial Club for the loan of their premises. Moderate prices were wisely charged, and baying was, consequently, brisk ; the stalls rapidly nnder went a process of denudation, aod by five o'olook, wheu the admission oharge was reduced and many townspeople fl joked in, the bulk of the goods were sold and had disappeared. j

Side shows were held throoghout the after ■ noon, and a special feature was the dinner | given from 7 to 9 p.m., which prored very attractive, aod added not a little to the sooia- j ability ot the oooasion and to the profits realized. The two English ladies to whom the credit of this part of the entertainment was doe were ably seconded by a staff of gentlemen and ladies, the former of whom, dressed as "chef* de cuisine," were kept Bteadily employed at carving, while the latter, daiotily arrayed a« waitresses, flitted to and fro falfllling the orders of the not too captions gnests with exemplary rapidity.

The gross takings of the bazaar are said to have been about JE 175, from wbioh only a smal sum for expeuaes had to be ded oted. The poor of Nioosis, among whom these proceeds are to be distributed, may well be grateful for the efforts made on their behalf. In a small o m inanity such b&ztars entad a very considerable amount of hard work and aotual expense to those who are responsible for getting them up If a repetition is contemplated for any future date, a certain sum might well be set aside from the present prooeeds to form a fund with which goods for sale might be purobased The Queen of G eqce graciously forwarded some articles for sale, but, unfortunately, they arrived too late, a contretemps which happened , also in one or two other instances. Several of oar owo townspeople who were in Nioosia at the time visited the bazaar and made pnrohasej.
Parfuma Farming.

It is reported that perfame farming on a somewhat extensive scale is about to be undertaken, nnder expert direction, in the neigh boorhord of Limassol. Should this bo so, a new and pr< fitable industry may be established in Cyprus in the near future Quite a number of plants grow well in this Island from which some of the beat known essential oils are distilled or extrao'ed for nse in the menu faotare of soaps and perfames. For some years past the Agricultural Department has undertaken the distillation of origanum (thyme) oil, for which a ready sale is f mud id England and the Continent at remunerative prices. The plant grows wild In the forests *nd, doubtless, oould, without difficulty, be cultivated in many of the more hilly parts of the Island. 0;her fimiliar plants here, which yield perf ime oils, an the geraoium j graine, sage mint, orange, damask rose, cypress, and the list oould yet be ^ddsd to. Uuder skilled management these oobld be extensively grown and a profitable industry might easily be developed.
The Linnssol Steamship Company has jos* issued a useful bookie", giviug information respecting the mail servioe between Cyprus and Egypt, with a Weekly itinerary for the vinter months

div.head: LE CANAL MAHMOUDIEH
div.p: LE CANAL MAHMOUDIEH
Monsieur le Directeur
de l1* Egyptian Gazette."

J apprends que la question du Canal Mahj mondieh est de noaveau sur le tapla, et que très prochainement le projet dn nouveau CanaJ Nonzha Mex serait adopté sans tambour ni trompette, et snrtoqt sans consultation appa; rente des intéressés.

Il est certes très bean de vouloir améliorer la situation existante à coup de millions, eq dotant la navigation fluviale à Alexandria d'nn canal nouveau, d'entrepôts, de moyens de déchargement rapide, mais encore est-il indispensable, me semble-t-il, de ne pas sq contenter d'an projet parement administratif Les grands travaux qne l'on projette doivent profiter an Coimneroe et uniquement an Commerce de l'Egypte, tant à l'importation qo'f 1 exportation ; par conséquent, il est an moinq raisonnable que le Commerce soit oonsolté soit par voie do referendum, soit par l'entreraisq de ses oorps constitués, en l'espèce les Chambres de Commerce des diverses oolonies, leq associations du Commerce d'importation et} d'Exportation. Il ne semble guère que l'on, veuille entrer dans cette voie, et poor ma, part, je tiens an moins à protester hautement; contre ce projet, d'abord parce qu'il n'a pas, été élaboré et discuté publiquement, ensuite) paroe qu'en admettant sa prompte exécution, il ne s'écoulera pas moins de nombreuse» années avant qn'un batean oironle sor ce canal, et qne les docks, quais, grues, etc., soient en état de rendre des servioes.
Q.ne tera-t-on en attendant ]

Un nous laissera patauger dans les vases du Canal aotnel, qn'on se gardera bien naturelle ment d'améliorer énormément, puisqu'il doit devenir, d'après le nouveau projet, une sorte de bassin sans iasne.

Non, vraiment, le nonveau projet n'a pas dn tout mes sympathies. On possède actuelle*, ment un canal qni depuis la prise d'ean del l'Atfeh jnrqn'à Minet-el Bassal ne gêne anonne ment le trafic des voies ferrées ; ce canal a sa rire gauobe inoccupée jnsqn'au cœur de Minet-el Bassal, et offre doro une occasion splendide de l'élargir. An lieu de cela, on se- propose d'établir nn nonvean bras de canal partant dn Jardin Nonzha, conpant la voie, ferrés Gebbari Mellaha jnste à la fin des gares, rie triage et de formation sctce'lep qui devront encore être agrandies dans peu de temps

Voilàdono les deux prar ds ooorants dn trafic des marchandises de l'Egypte, le Chemin de Fer et la Navigation Fluvia'equ', près de leur print de départ eommur, se rencontrent ponT se contrarier mutuellement. Il est évident qu'il faut qne le pont qui se trouvera an croisement dn Canal s'onvre à certaines heures. A ces moments-là, qae 00 soit le jour on la nuit, il faudra pendaut certains espaces de temps, dont le minimum me semble être nue benre, arrêter le mouvement du Chemin de Per D'on antre côté, le Chemin de Fer, administration gouvernementale, établira l'horaire d'ouverture des ponts comme cela loi conviendra, et la navigation fluviale se trouvera encore une fois en manvai-e po«tare, car si non» considérons simplement le mouvement actuel des barques aux abord» des ponts, oe n'est pas one ouverture d'nne heure, tro's on quatre fois par 24 heure» qui pourra suffire pour régulariser le trati', fluvial, s'il continue à se développer comme il le fait depuis deux ans, 09 dont je n'ai pas l'ombie d'on doote.

Ponr s'en rendre oompte, i' fant aller la nnit examiner oomment s'effectuent dans les condition» aotnelles le passage des barque» an Mahmoodieh, et il faut aussi aller se promener près de la digne du ohemin de fer Mellaha- Gabbari la nuit ; on y verra te mouvement incessant des trains et des rangée» de wagons qui manœuvrent sur oes voie» ferrée» m>eux éolairées que n'importe quelle rne d'Alexandrie.

Je crois en avoir asspz dit snr le pont; pas sons au canal à travers le Lie Maré >tis. C'est nn travail pen ordinaire que de creuser nn canal dans les vases d'an lao qui n'a ponr lai q»'un avantage, son pen de profondeur. Il faudra nu certain temp', mu semble t il, ponr qia les mars de remblai entre lesquel s coulera le futnr canal soient term'nés et surtout établis d'ane faç m assez solide. Au point de vnô de I art la l'Ingénieur, ce sera un beaa travail; an au point de vue dp Trésor Egyptien, autrement dit de notre poche à tous, oe sera une be1 le dépense. Mais enfin, admettons que oe tronÇ >n du cinal s'achève sans incident ot par Ions des installations de tous genres dont ses rives vont être pourvue» au Mex.
L endroit exaot n'est pas encore bien dêter miné; le canal aboatiradans la mer, près da Sémaphore, ou bien au-dela près de l'Abattoir, a -je lu quelque part.

Four le trorçun de cana1, s'étendant du Lac il la mer, il est question d'en faire un bras de iner avec une écluse à l'endroit où 'e canal dé b nicherait du lao Maré itis. Ca bras dj mer serait le n yau d'au quartier des eutrepô's, il serait bordé de large» quais permettant une prompte manutention des marchandée» an moyen d'appareil» de levage perfectionné -, C'est là que vieudraieuts'emmagasinerd'uiK ôté -es produits du pays destinés à ['exportation et de . autre le» nombreuses marchandises à transporter vers l'iu'érienr dn pays. On aurait là ri»s ins^al'ations spacieuses et du terrain pour bâtir des chonnabs et des magasins tant qu'on voudrait.

C'est très bien, mais déplaoe-t-on ainsi, à nne telle distanoe de son emplacement aotae), tont le quartier des eotrepô'x d'une ville, quartier à sa physionomie spéciale, et oh le terrain ne manque pas encore pour le développer. D'ud entre côté, est-on bien sûr que do jour au len demain, l'on verra sortir de terre des entrepôts fi° Mex. Pense-t-on que de gaieté de ccear, les

exportateurs vont alltr abandonner leurs ohouj naha actuelles et s'installer trois kilmuèlri n plus loin. De plus, la spéculation snr terrains vi> nécessairement s'en mêler, et l'on risque fort de voir oe nouveau quartier do» installations maritimes avoir des débuts difficiles, à cause du ooût élevé des terrainp. tandis qne Minet- el Bassal sera pins encombré qne jamais de marchandise»

Si réellement le projet dn nonvean oanal doit être mi» à exéontion, il est absolument nécessaire qne le Gouvernement demeure propriétaire de ton» les terrain» rh dos magasin» doivent s'élever, oonstrnise lni-rrêroe le» entrepôt» et le» lone ensuite anx particuliers,comme cela >e fait dan» les grand» ports maritimes d'Europe. Pinon. rien d étonnant, à dp éohec dn prrje», si on laisse la spéculation s'en mêler, et vo*rs ponvez, être assurés qu'elle est déjà très occupée de oe oôté là, sans en avoir l'air. Dn dernier mot an snjei de l'ntili»ation prat qne du canal dans sa section maritime : il est évident que les allèges pouvant venir accoster le long des entrepôts sans perdre nn long temps à des éolnses, auront nn grand avantage, do trême que les chalands à vapeur qui pourront ainsi oironler facilement dans le port. Mais qne l'on fasse bien attention à la façon d*mt on va protéger l'entrée du canal (fan» la nul-. La m°r est bien traîtresse de ce iôé là et s'il n'entre pas en première ligne de compte d'établir des jetées et des brises lsmes capables d'ashnrer l'accès dn oanal à toute» h » embaroation» par tons les temps, on risque encore bien d'avoir de» mécomptes. Il est vrai qne l'on construit nn nonvean brise-lames près de l'Abattoir, perpendiculaire à la côte, précisément afin de rendre la rade de notre port accessible par toos le» temps; reste à voir si ce brise-lame» sera suffisant et si d'antres travaux d'art ne seront pas indispensables. (Jn'on se souvienne deR mécomptes de la cale sèche à côté dn Sémaphore.

Comme fiche de consoLtinr, on snuo> 00 en même temps que l'on »'i {forcera ^0 remédier le mienx possible an trafic toujours croissant du Mshmondieh aotnel devenu trop étroit et j insuffisant, dont on supprimera les écluses. Ce sont des promesses, mais il semble qne depuis . deux ans que le trafic du port d'Alexandrie s'est élevé au-delà de tonte prévision, ni le Gouvernement, ni la Municipalité n'ont fait nn pas pour améliorer l'acheminement des marchandises ve»s lTn'érieor par la voie fin viale

On répondra à oe'a que le Gouvernement j possédant les ohetuios de fer n'a pas trop à ! favoriser la voie d'eau C'e-f pr»»ib'p, mais la ! Municipalité qui cb«rrhe ft ar-o fi r son budget ( par des taxe» notive le , e-f ,e ©ridant bien la ' première intéressée an développement rapide ( de la ville d'Alexandrie, spécialement an point j de vue commercial et industriel. Q-i'a-t elle fait ponr le Canal ? E'ie a décidé d'exécuter trois p-'-Dts et c'est tont.

(Li 10pout cependa i* pa» aller se promener an Canal du Gabbary ju q 1 aux Champs J* y sées, sans se demander comment i! est possible que l'on n'ait encore mn essayé de faire pour améliorer le trafic fl ivial.

Ceci pourrait se faire immédiatement, en attendant l'achèvement dn f-menx nonvean oaral ; le ('anal rc'rp| serait ainsi utilisé jnsqn'an maximum de son re- dement po»»iblp. j Puisque chacun y va do son potit pr- jet, 1 j voioi le mien :

A partir dn dernier pont snr le C*nal (Pont ( Z'itfioar,) jnsqn an coude devant l'Usine de» Tramways, expropriation snr nne profondeur de quarante mètres des ponstrnotion» de la rive droite (rôté de la ville) et abaissement de celle | oi à la cote de 3 u-ètres an dessus du niveau dn 1 Canal. Il n'y a 'à qne qne'ques vieilles obon- ' nahs ; ce serait donc facile. An oonde devant 8 l'Usine des Tramways se trouve nn vaste t«r- : rain en contre bas de la routp. dn rôté du Lao, * et compris entre le Canal, le Chemin de fer. et I l'Lysine à R'Z de MM B'unonh II s'agirait r d'utiliser re terrain cotnm» bassin réservé e nniqnement aoxSooiéfésde navigation fluviale.

On aarait là une vaste snp*rti:ie d ean bordée de qnais, de magasins et de grnes, ( fi le» cha lands pourraient évoloer s»n» encombrer comme à présent le Canal. Par le tait même dn erru sement de ce bassin, les rives do Canal dé barrassée» des dé, ô'.s des oempagnies de navigation fluviale» redeviendraient libres, et pourraient être bordées de quais.

Eu même temps, on devrait exproprier les terrains sur le» denx rives du Cana', depuis 'Usine des Tramway» je qu'à la rue Ragheb Pacha, snr nne largeur de tra ite mètres ponr y établir des en'repôts et de» quais de quinze mètres de large. Oc anrait ainsi immédiatement et facilement le moyen de soulager la partie de Minet-el-Baasal comprise entre les ponts, qui est absolument congestionnée, à caoRe dn pen d'endroits ih l'accostage des barques et chalands soit possib'e en raison de la hauteur ridicule des murs du () : ai.

Entr6 le PotP Vieux et len Ecluses, Il oon- i viendrait aussi de faire dLparatre le» Cboa n»b» oomprisea entre le» magasins do Cbrm'n de Fer et la roe longeant le Canal, pour établir là nn quai de déba-quement avec rampes an bord dn canal et une large rne donnant aooès anx denx porte» de la Douane de oe cô'é là oh le mouvement eat intense.
On fera ainsi rer dre an Canal dan» oette partie ls des services qu'il ne rend pas actuellement et on augmentera beaucoup, par le fait , même, sa capaoité utilisable.

Je ne donne ici que les grandes lignes d'nn projet, mais j'engage tou» ceux qni ont a cœur les vraie intéiêta du commerce Alexandrin et en particulier le* exportateurs à se rendre sur les lieux et à examiner par eux-mêmes si ce qne je propose n'est pas réalisable en fort pen de temps. Il y a certainement moyen d'élever encore de 50 % 1* capaoi té d'atilisation aotnel le da oanel, et cela par des travaux simples, évidemment ooûfenx, mais qui anront l'approbation. de tons cenx qui ont des intérêts daDS le oommeroe de notre ville.
Une véritable ruobe d'établissement* indns- triels oommeooe à ie former le long do Canal;
toutes ces industriel) sont nne eonrofl de pros
périté nouvelle et direote peu r la ville , ou doit donc au*<ii loi ir u . pen oompte de leur» inté.
ê's e* b'pi »-> 'ire qne ce i.'est pas seulement, pour avoir <'o l'eau facilement ponr leurs ohao dières qu elles sont venues là, maie aussi pool} être à proximité du ohemin de fer et d'aq canal.

Ja prends maintenant la question à un autre poiut de voe : le oharroi des marchandises par oharrettes. Supposons que Minet el-Ba»s*l garde son aspeot actael et sou trafio d'»n- juord'hui. Conviendra-t il d'amener an Mex: du Coton à embarquer sur vapeurs. Il n'estj pas toujours dit q ie le» ohalands à vapeur iront se mettre dans le port le long du bord de» vapeurs pour y livrer directement leni car-] Raison; il y aura dono des frais élevés de rt p-.r charrettes, ce qui amènera for-| cément leg . xportatfnrs à faire toujours arriver I > coton à Minet-el Bassal de préférenoe. De même pour les marchandises à expédier, dans l'intérieur dn pays, leur oonvoyage jusqu'au Mex nécessitera des frais de obarrette» importants, et leur transport par allèges de la Douane ne oauvieulra guère

Noo. q i on améliore le Mahmoudieh im médiatement par tous les moyens possible» qu'on s'efforce d'abord de donner immédiate-, tuent satisfaction aux besoins présents de ly navigation fluviale. Pourquoi ne donne t-on même pa» actuellement au oanal salargear, réelle, et ne le drxgau t on pas. A ch qae tournant .L. Ornai en ville, il y a de» banc» da sable *.t di vas?. Près de l'Usine des Trams, le» riverains plantent leur» légume», en oontre-bas de la berge. Eu face de la* Kafr Z.yat Cotton Co one mahonne est oonléel juste -ni milirn du canal, depuis lopgt-'mp».

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: La Cain», Samedi 5 Janvier 1907

Le taux de l'e«s inapte libre à Londres a été à nonveaa réduit hier de 1/8 k 5 poor oent. Sa 8tock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a encore haussé de non moins de 3/8 à 87 1/4. L'Unifiée est restée invariée k102 1/4, de même q 'e la National Bank à 28 1/2, l'Agrioole k 9 f 8, la Daira à 17 1 fi et la Delta Light à 12.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est de
menré inchangé à 783. La Banqne d' Athènes
a regagné 1 franc à 140.

Notre marché des valeurs tend k prendre nne physionomie générale de pins en pins sa tisfaisaute. Ce matin, doob avons en nne séance très animée aveo des transactions abondantes La fermeté reprend décidément le dessns, et la demande recommence & prédominer l'offre. I,e mouvement a principalement porté sur les Nungovioh et Egyptian Hotels, les E treprises Immobilières et Travanx, l'Epargne Immobilière, l'Express Nile, les Jouissances Eiux di Caire, la Delta Land, la Cassa di Soontn, la Banqne d'Athènes, la Daira, eto.

La National Bank s'est maintenue è 28 7 1<>, de même que l'Agrioole k 9 5/8 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a réaotionnék 29U La Banqne d'Athènes a gagné 3 francs è 137 138. Le Comptoir s'est raffermi k 8 1 H 3/16 et sa part à 94 95.
Le Crédit Fonoicr a é*é areux tenu à 779. La Daïra a avancé à 17 5/8 11/16 L'Union Fonoière est à 6 1/4 5/16.

Ainsi que nous l avions fait pressentir hier, l'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a passé de L E. 15 à 17 1/4, en très bonne demande. Eu Bourse on s'attend généralement à ce que des surprises encore plan agréables soiut réservées bientôt aux détenteurs de ce titre. La part de fondateur a haussé de P.E 160 à 174 pour olôtarer à 170.

La part de fondateur Epargne Immobilière a haussé graduellement de P.E 143 à 170, acheteurs. Los vendeurs se font de plus en plus rares. On prévoit en Bourse une forte nouvelle poussée, oar les acheteurs ne trouvent pas de contrepartie et veulent quand même prendre position.
Tout aussi favorisée, la part Express Nile a passé de 142 à 158 en forte demande.
En très banne tenue, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont encore bénéficié de 7 franos à 294. La part de la Société Egyptienne do Pu blioité a atteint P.K 350.
Dans le groupe des va'eurs hôtelière', les Nungovioh se sout consolidés k 22 7/8. Les Egyptian ont avancé à 12 9/16-5/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land se sont maintenus fermement k 4 3/4 La part de foadatear Estates a progressé k 21 5/8. Les New Egyptian ont avancé à 33 sh. 3 et les Oasis k1 3,16.

Hier matin, vers 10 heures et demie, la fiihe portant les noms de MM H. de Vries A Bou- tigey a été enlevés du tableau des Agents de ohaoge, apposé kla Bourse da Caire, sur le quel figure la nomenclature de tocs les mom- bres de la Corporation.

Après avoir fait constater le fait par plusieurs témoins, MM. H. de Vriei A Boutiguy ont aussitôt fait sommation, par voie d'huissier, k M. Paul Oziol, en sa qualité de président de U Corporation, d'avoir k rétablir immédiatement leurs noms sur le tableau; fau'e de qno<, M. Paul Oziol serait tenu responsable de tout préjudice moral et matériel pouvant résulter de oette subtilisation.

Or, après avoir reçu signification de la sommation, ce matin vers 9 h. 30, M. Panl Oziol a donné incontinent les instructions nécessaires pour que oett? plaisanterie de mauvais aloi f>rlt fin, et les noms de MM. H. de Vries & Boatigny figareut actuellement à nouveau sur le tablean.
Il serait, nous en convenons, ridioule d'atta cher nne importance outrée à ces agissements
Toujours est-il qu'ils établissent éloqaem
ment l'état d'esprit qui règne ohez les gei s
auxquels la Corporation a confié le manda'
de régir le marohé financier de la capitale.

Il y aora cessation d'affaires k la Boorse du Caire lundi prochain 7 Janvier k l'occasion de la Nui! grecque et, très probablement, le leude main mardi 8 Janvier, anniversaire de l'avéne- meut de 3. A. le Kbélive, l'établissement de la rue Maghrabi se disant "Khédivial.''
Dans ce dernier oas, le prochain No de notre Circulaire ne paraîtrait que le mercredi 8 Jan vier 1907.

Le procès intenté pat la Sooiété Générale de Paris k MM. Oziol, Jabès et^Cie. en réclamation de francs 289 553,10, représentant le montant au prinoipal de 2,132 actions, reliquat des 4000 souscrite! lors de l'augmentation du capital de l'Ibrahimieh Ploughing Co.,a été appelé ce matin par devant la Chambre commerciale du Tribanal mixte de première instance da Caire (No du rôle général 1287, XXXlIème année judiciaire).
Me Carton de Wiart s'est présenté pour 1» Sooiété Générale de Parii et Me Fatioa pour la maison Oziol, Jabès et Cie. L'afïdire a été reuvoyée pour être plaidée au samedi 23 lé vrier proohain.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
